title: Schapelle Corby: Kerri-Anne Kennerley confronts drug smuggler on air
text:
Convicted drug trafficker Schapelle Corby had an awkward exchange with Kerri-Anne Kennerley during a live appearance on Studio 10 on Wednesday.

The fluffy interview took a serious turn when Kennerley, 66, asked Corby about the profits from her 2006 autobiography, My Story, which was re-released in updated form with additional chapters this week.

Referencing Australian laws that prohibit criminals from profiting from books and films about their crimes, Kennerley asked who exactly was making money from the revised edition of My Story.

Don't mention the money! Convicted drug trafficker Schapelle Corby had an awkward exchange with Kerri-Anne Kennerley during a live appearance on Studio 10 on Wednesday

Corby, 42, avoided the question, replying: 'Well, it is not about money. It is about me finishing my story. It is about going back and being cathartic to myself and my supporters, to let them know what really happened.'

She added: 'But to get back to you, it's not about money.'

Studio 10 panelist Joe Hildebrand then quickly added: 'And you are not being paid for this interview, we should stress, as well.'

'Where will the profits go?' The fluffy interview took a serious turn when Kennerley (left) asked Corby (right) about the profits from her 2006 autobiography, My Story, which was re-released in updated form with additional chapters this week

Hard-hitting question: Referencing Australian laws that prohibit criminals from profiting from books and films about their crimes, Kennerley asked who exactly was making money from the revised edition of My Story

Kennerley pushed for a definitive answer, asking Corby once again: 'It is not about money, but where will the profits go?'

'I am not sure... It's true, I am not sure,' Corby said. 'Why would you bring yourself to do something like this for... I don't know. All I know is I needed to finish this book.'

The new edition of My Story, co-authored by Corby and journalist Kathryn Bonella, is 'fully revised and updated' and documents Corby's life since her release from Bali's Kerobokan Prison in 2014 and her deportation to Australia two years ago.

Media rounds: Earlier on Wednesday, Schapelle had been interviewed on KIIS FM's The Kyle and Jackie O Show (pictured)

Legal woes: Corby became a household name after she was arrested in October 2004 at Bali's Ngurah Rai Airport with 4.1kg of marijuana wrapped in plastic inside her boogie board bag

Corby became a household name after she was arrested in October 2004 at Bali's Ngurah Rai Airport with 4.1kg of marijuana wrapped in plastic inside her boogie board bag.

She was later sentenced to 20 years in prison, but after a series of sentence reductions was released on parole in February 2014 after nine years behind bars.

In May 2017, she was deported back to Australia amid a media frenzy.
description: Convicted drug trafficker Schapelle Corby had an awkward exchange with Kerri-Anne Kennerley during a live appearance on Studio 10 on Wednesday.
authors: Jo Scrimshire For Daily Mail Australia
